section_title: Washington International Horse Show — Venue Profile
section_overview: WIHS in Upper Marlboro brings big-city production to a polished indoor setting with efficient ring flow and tight call times. Expect a primary show ring inside The Show Place Arena with adjacent schooling, a clearly posted jog strip, and a compact vendor row for last-minute fixes. Stabling is organized and walkable; plan your hack routes and allow extra minutes at peak to thread golf-cart traffic. Footing and drags are posted and enforced—check the board before you tack up so you hit the warm-up ring at the right moment.

section_spotlight.title: Quick Hits for WIHS
bullets: Warm-up: traffic stacks up ahead of eq, junior jumpers, and FEI sessions—flat early and call your lines with the ingate.
Ring flow: add 5–10 minutes from stabling to in-gate during peak; use outer lanes to avoid golf-cart pinch points.
Jog strip: number visible, tack tidy—arrive early with a towel and hoof oil for last-second touch-ups.
Vendor row: fast fixes—studs, spur straps, braiding yarn, and coffee; call ahead for quick pick-ups between trips.
Stabling: aisles stay busy—trunks flush, fans secured, hoses coiled; use designated lunging/hand-grazing only.
Footing & drags: posted intervals are enforced—check boards so your schooling aligns with drags and course walks.
Course walks: arena access is timed—have a ring bag ready (hole punch, zip ties, electrical tape, rub rag).
Badges & parking: credential checks at arena doors—keep your wristband/credential handy to avoid delays.
Weather watch: mid-Atlantic swing can be cool and damp—pack layers and plan conservative studs after rain.
Pro tip: text your groom from vendor row when you’re 10 out—saves a trip and keeps the horse relaxed at stabling.
